headline: Kobbie Mainoo faces stark Man Utd warning as Ruben Amorim's true feelings questioned
body: Kobbie Mainoo has been served a harsh dose of reality as speculation continues around his Manchester United future. The 20-year-old has become one of Old Trafford's most discussed figures this season, despite barely featuring on the pitch.

Mainoo hasn't been given a single Premier League start under Ruben Amorim this term and has only started once across all competitions in a shocking Carabao Cup exit to League Two outfit Grimsby Town back in August. Despite his limited game time, the England international continues to attract attention from European giants Napoli and Bayern Munich, who are reportedly keeping tabs on his situation.

Mainoo even sought a loan switch late in the summer transfer window, raising doubts about his standing in Amorim's plans. The Portuguese manager insisted this week that the youngster remains integral to his vision for the club, even branding him the "future of Manchester United".
But former Premier League striker Dean Saunders believes the hype around Mainoo has spiralled beyond what he's actually achieved, whilst questioning whether Amorim truly means what he says.

Speaking on talkSPORT, the ex-Wolves and Wrexham boss said: "I've never known a player get so much airtime and so much press without kicking a ball. He's in the back pages of the paper every day. Mainoo this, Mainoo that and he hasn't started since Grimsby away in the cup when they got knocked out.

"They were horrendous against Grimsby and I think sometimes, as a manager, you watch that game and you think, 'that's it, he's never playing again. He [Amorim] has played Fernandes in that role with Casimero and he [Mainoo] has not got the chance to play.

"It won't go on forever, because he's played for England and he's shown his potential. He scored a couple of good goals, but I don't think he does know that position. He [Amorim] has just gone, 'I've had enough of this every day. Mainoo this, Mainoo that. I'll put it to bed by just saying he's not going anywhere.'".
The harsh assessment stands in stark contrast to Amorim's public support, after the United manager dismissed any talk of a January departure.
He said: "He's going to be the future of Manchester United, that is my feeling. He just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football in two days.

"Kobbie Mainoo will have the opportunity he has all the time. He played in different positions; he can do that [defensive midfield] position, he can play if we play with three, he can play like we play in the last game - the position of Mason Mount in this game [against Villa]."

Amorim subsequently dismissed speculation about Mainoo departing Old Trafford next month, saying: "If we are not getting someone, it is hard to leave. Even with a full squad we are shorter [in terms of players] for something that can happen here so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution."

However, despite being recently sidelined with a calf injury, there are ongoing queries about why Mainoo hasn't been able to secure a spot in Amorim's starting line-up. Saunders suggests that a short-term loan move overseas could be beneficial for the midfielder, identifying Italy as an ideal place for development.

He added: "He's shown potential, but this is Man United we're talking about. They're trying to win everything they enter. They're a massive club and in that number six position, you have to smell danger from all angles.
"I think, for a young lad to learn that, it's difficult unless he's playing every week. I think you're doing good if you go to Napoli or somewhere like that, one of these Italian teams."

headline: Man Utd handed new referee verdict after Lisandro Martinez flashpoint vs Newcastle
body: Ex-Premier League referee Keith Hackett has backed Anthony Taylor's decision not to award Newcastle a penalty for a handball by Manchester United captain Lisandro Martinez.

During the match on Boxing Day, a shot from Fabian Schar hit the stand-in United captain inside the six-yard box. Despite Martinez's claims to referee Taylor, that the ball had struck him in the stomach, replays suggested his arm had made contact with the ball.

Video assistant referee Stuart Attwell reviewed that incident, but decided against any further action. Hackett, who previously served as the general manager of Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL), has now given his verdict on the contentious decision.

Speaking to Football Insider, Hackett said: "The referee has to judge if the action by the player is deliberate when deciding that an offence has taken place, not every time the ball comes into contact, is it an offence. There is sufficient doubt in this action not to award a penalty kick."
"Schar hits it, his arm is up above his head, and it's stretched. Is it because he's pushing [Malick] Thiaw?
"That might just save him. He's actually wrestling with the other Newcastle centre-back; his arms are already there.
"If Thiaw is nowhere near him, then that's definitely a penalty. I think the fact that he has just had a wrestle with the other centre-back might just save him."

Neville also revealed what the VAR officials made of the controversial moment. The pundit added: "He's saying the context is because there's another situation whereby he's fighting with another player, and his arm's are already up there and he's just not got back down."
Main commentator Peter Drury explained: "They are calling it mutual contact between Martinez and Thiaw. And that's essentially the explanation for the fact that there won't be a penalty."

Following United's triumph, head coach Ruben Amorim heaped praise on Martinez. He said: "I think he's a guy with a lot of character. He's really good on the ball, and that came with the quality that he has.

"He played [in the] World Cup, he won [the] World Cup. He's used to that stress, and he showed today that he's a top player, and sometimes people talk about the way he defends the box because he's a small guy, but today he did really well against a team that just has tall players."

Yet when he was in turn pressed on whether the squad would be stronger with Martinez maintaining his fitness, Amorim declined to single out individuals. He responded: "No, I don't want to say that because - if we don't have more points - it's because of the team, not because of a specific player."

headline: Marcus Rashford's decision on January transfer says it all about Man Utd exile's character
body: Much has changed in the 12 months since Marcus Rashford first signalled that he wanted to move on from Manchester United. The 28-year-old is currently experiencing something of a career revival with Barcelona, but his outlook once appeared far less encouraging after a breakdown in his relationship with United head coach Ruben Amorim.

Following 18 months of poor form and with Amorim determined to shape his team around a strong, central No. 9, Rashford found himself at a crossroads. Despite being born and raised in Manchester, Rashford had carried ambitions that stretched beyond Old Trafford.
Barcelona was always his dream move abroad. However, getting to the Camp Nou was never going to come easily and demanded both patience and resilience.

When the January transfer window opened, talks with the Catalan giants took place, but a deal was never reached. Instead, Rashford sealed a loan switch to Aston Villa on deadline day, viewing it as a chance to rebuild his damaged standing.

He managed just four goals in 17 games at Villa Park, yet his overall contribution in the West Midlands proved sufficient to reignite Barcelona's interest later that summer. "I just believe that things happen when they're supposed to happen," Rashford told ESPN in October.

"It's not the first time I spoke with Barcelona about potentially coming here, but for whatever reasons it didn't happen in the past and now is my opportunity to make it happen. I feel like there's no time like the present now. So I just take things day to day.

"The key thing for me is just to continue to improve because when you retire, you're going to miss everything - the good stuff, the bad stuff - you're going to miss it about the sport. Every day I just take it day by day and just try to improve from the day before."

Those comments underline Rashford's mindset - an aspect of his career that was often examined closely during his spell at United. The England forward frequently faced criticism for his conduct on and off the field, but a renewed sense of purpose and a quieter dedication to his work appear to have transformed perceptions and produced clear results.

"I was clear on my preference from the beginning," Rashford explained after completing his move to Barcelona in July. "It didn't work out in January so I went to Aston Villa and enjoyed a good period there. I'm very grateful for the opportunity to play there.
"The summer came around very quickly, it was time to make another decision. My choice was easy."

Life at Barcelona has suited Rashford well so far. He has established himself as a near constant presence in Hansi Flick's line-up, sitting out just one of Barcelona's 25 fixtures across all competitions to date.

Statistics back up his importance. Rashford has delivered nine goals and 11 assists, with his influence especially evident in the Champions League, where he has been directly involved in seven goals in six matches.

That resurgence has also helped him reclaim a regular role with England. As Barcelona are widely expected to make his loan deal permanent next year, Rashford's call to leave last January - no matter where he landed - looks increasingly astute.

headline: Ruben Amorim faces nervous Man Utd wait during next game after triple AFCON blow
body: Patrick Dorgu will have to be on his best behaviour against Wolves next week if he wants to avoid a suspension. The full-back, who scored the winner in the 1-0 clash with Newcastle United on Boxing Day, is currently walking a tightrope.

The 21-year-old has totted-up four yellow cards this season after 18 games. Collecting five before reaching the 19-match threshold of a campaign triggers an automatic one-match ban for any Premier League player.

This means Dorgu - and his manager for that matter - face a tense 90 minutes against Wolves in their next fixture, with three teammates unavailable due to the Africa Cup Of Nations and Bruno Fernandes amongst those still side-lined through injury.

After being dropped and openly criticised by Ruben Amorim just a few weeks earlier, Dorgu has forced his way back into their starting XI with an assist (vs Aston Villa) and goal (vs Newcastle), helping United feel significantly more secure despite their depleted squad.

"He needs to be calmer playing the game," Amorim said during a press conference when asked about what Dorgu needs to work on, adding: "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."

After that press conference, Dorgu was dropped from the United starting line-up. He was subsequently named among the substitutes for the following five fixtures, before then being brought back into the fold against Villa.

Speaking to reporters after the final whistle against Newcastle, Dorgu addressed how he's handled recent criticism. He said: "Of course, it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player.
"And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago. I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

Now perhaps a guaranteed starter for the Wolves clash on December 30, Dorgu has carved out a fresh role in the revamped line-up. But one mistake against the bottom-placed team will see the Denmark international suspended for a crucial trip to Leeds United.
Amorim will be desperate to have the ex-Lecce man available for the journey to Elland Road. A few weeks back, however, he might not have anticipated relying on him so heavily.

Brought back into the fold out of necessity due to three teammates being away at AFCON, Dorgu has, on initial evidence, seized his opportunity. The last thing he'll want now is to lose his grip on the starting place and hand a similar chance to another squad member under Amorim.

Dorgu arrived at the club courtesy of Amorim during last season's January transfer window, with United paying £30million for his services. In his time wearing United's colours, the wing-back has racked up 38 appearances.

His strike against Newcastle marked his maiden goal for the club, complementing his three assists along the way. Dorgu, who has earned 12 senior caps for Denmark, is also tied to Old Trafford until 2030.

headline: Roy Keane and Gary Neville agree after Ruben Amorim FINALLY makes key Man Utd change
body: Ayden Heaven was showered with praise after earning the man of the match award in Manchester United’s backs-to-the-wall win over Newcastle on Boxing Day. Heaven is just 19 years old and was making just his 13th appearance for the club in a new position, but shone at Old Trafford.

United were without Bruno Fernandes, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt for the game, while Mason Mount also went off injured. Meanwhile, Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui are away at the Africa Cup of Nations, forcing Ruben Amorim to adapt.

The home side took the lead through Patrick Dorgu’s stunning volley from a Diogo Dalot long throw-in and then managed to weather the storm of Newcastle pressure. Key to their victory was the performance of Heaven, who slotted in at right centre-back, despite being left-footed.

Amorim has been stubborn in his use of a 3-4-2-1 formation since becoming United boss, but did adapt against Newcastle, with a rare back four often resembling a back six in the latter stages of the match. It helped United keep just their second clean sheet of the season and their first since a 2-0 win over Sunderland on October 4.

Former United defender Gary Neville added: “Manchester United hung in there. Heaven was absolutely brilliant. Those Newcastle players… four or five of them collapsed to the ground at the end. Heaven has been the man of the match.”

“This guy (Dorgu) here helped us get there, so thankful to everyone that helped us. It was different, I was playing on the right side, obviously my weaker foot. The manager, we play loads of formations with him, whatever he does we know it’s going to work, you saw today. I’m so proud of the team.”

Amorim praised his players for toughing out the win despite seeing little of the ball and was particularly happy with his young defender. “I'm really pleased with Ayden. You can feel that he’s improving every game,” he said. “He's young, but you don't feel that he has a good game and then he slows the game or the thinking during the game.

“No, you feel that he’s improving during the game. I think he was not playing, but he trained really well. You just need to train really well to be ready when the opportunity comes. So, in this moment, if you continue to play like that, it's going to be really hard to take his place.”

headline: Ruben Amorim's dilemma is obvious as Man Utd fans make feelings crystal clear
body: It's been a tough year for Manchester United fans. The Red Devils finished 15th - their worst position in Premier League history - lost a European final and failed to win a domestic trophy.

Ruben Amorim's credentials are still being questioned on a weekly basis, and on paper, many would argue that he's in charge of the weakest United squad of the post-Sir Alex Ferguson era. That's despite another injection of £215million over the summer.
One player who's still shining, however, is Bruno Fernandes. That is until he got injured.

Red Devils captain Fernandes went off at half-time with a hamstring problem during last Sunday's toothless 2-1 loss away to Aston Villa. His absence was immediately felt, as United showed little goal threat.

It was the same during their Boxing Day victory over Newcastle. Although Patrick Dorgu's strike gave them a 1-0 home win, Newcastle fired off six more shots and had treble the amount of touches in the opposition box.
Matthijs de Ligt came third with 36 votes while Casemiro earned 28. In fifth place, Harry Maguire got 19 - likely thanks to that special moment at Anfield.

The gulf between Fernandes and his team-mates is undeniable and Amorim must find a solution when he's missing. That's not just for this season either, as the 31-year-old has left the door open to a departure from Old Trafford next summer.
As for when he'll return from his injury, Amorim said earlier this week: "I don't want to say. I have an idea but let's see."

The United boss even told his players that Fernandes was 'impossible to replace'. "I said that this morning to the team," Amorim revealed. "We need to take the good thing - if there is a good thing on that - that a lot of people need to step up and understand we cannot rely on one player for everything.

"Sometimes we rely on Bruno for organisation and the creation. We have lost Bruno on set-pieces, Bryan [Mbeumo] and Amad on set-pieces, so this is massive for the team. But it is an opportunity for other players to step up and show the leadership that we need in the team."

headline: Ayden Heaven's Premier League ambitions speak volumes about Ruben Amorim at Man Utd
body: Ayden Heaven believes Manchester United could 'possibly push' to claim the Premier League title this season following their Boxing Day triumph over Newcastle United. Heaven earned man of the match honours for his display at Old Trafford after helping the Red Devils secure a clean sheet in their victory against the Magpies.
The 19-year-old said: "It was [big]- finally a clean sheet. We've been waiting for this for a couple of weeks. I'm just so happy. I'm so thankful for everyone who helped us [win].

"As Manchester United, we belong in Europe, and we want to get back there next season. We can push for the top four, possibly push for the league; anything is possible. We are just going to keep trying.
"The manager, we play loads of formations with him, whatever he does, we know it's going to work, you saw today. I'm so proud of the team."

However, Roy Keane has suggested United are not quite prepared to challenge for the title. The club's former skipper said during Sky's match coverage: "[Heaven] mentioned there about winning titles - they're not quite ready for that, but you have to start somewhere."

Heaven has previously voiced his confidence that United will return to UEFA competitions next season. Following their 4-1 triumph over Wolverhampton Wanderers in early December, he said: "I don't think anyone can stop us when we play like this. We want to win as many games as possible. Hopefully we can be in Europe next season, which I think we'll do."

Ruben Amorim also weighed in on when United might next clinch the league title, ahead of their final match before Christmas against Aston Villa. His comments came in response to Sir Alex Ferguson saying to Press Box PR that it could take his former club a decade or more to secure their next title.
The current United head coach responded: "He understands football more, especially English football. I don't think we'll take that long to win the league.
"I don't know which manager will be here, but I truly believe we can fight for the title in the next years. It is not going to take so many years, but you never know.
"In leadership, it's the moment of the club; you have to fight all the fights. We are improving as a team.

"As a group, we are going to improve in these small things. That will make a difference even to suffer goals. If we are a different group, we will suffer less goals, but we are scoring more, so let's think about the positives."

headline: Ruben Amorim given credit for major Man Utd change after 'anxiety' admission
body: United were riddled with injuries and were missing three players due to the Africa Cup of Nations but still came through to win. Dorgu was an unlikely match winner, having never scored for United in 37 games prior, yet took his goal expertly, volleying in a dropping ball after Diogo Dalot’s long throw-in was partially cleared.

His first goal wasn’t for lack of trying, with the left wing-back having attempted 30 shots previously without success. Confidence has been an issue for the Denmark international, who joined for £25million in February and has admitted to working on the mental side of the game with his manager.

“I just took what he (Ruben Amorim) told me to work on my confidence and stuff. I think I did well today. I just looked at the ball, saw it drop, and I just hit it. I've been practicing in training, so I think that's what helped me.”

His words echoed what Amorim had said in November about Dorgu. “He needs to be calmer playing the game,” the United boss said. “You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touched the ball, I can feel it, the anxiety.

“And I remember the shot [missed] against Everton. That was easier than the decision that he had to make when the guys from Scotland were there, when he made a great decision. And I saw it when he played in Italy. But, again, here is different and sometimes the pressure is hard for them in the beginning, but he has time to improve.”

Amorim added: “What I feel when I see them training, they are doing so much better than in games. When I see him playing for the national team, he’s scored a great goal against Scotland, the decision that he made under pressure was different to the decision that he’s making in our team.

“So I just need to understand the context in trying to help them. I think they are far from the best, and they know it. Like a lot of players in our team, like myself. I think they have so much more to give. Let’s see this week if we improve that.”
That improvement has been evident of late, with United now level on points with fourth-placed Chelsea and sixth-placed Liverpool, albeit their rivals have played a game fewer.

The raised performances are desperately needed, given United are currently without the injured Bruno Fernandes, Mason Mount, Harry Maguire and Matthijs de Ligt, while Bryan Mbeumo, Amad Diallo and Noussair Mazraoui are away at AFCON.

headline: Man Utd injury latest and return dates for Wolves after Mason Mount update
body: Manchester United beat Newcastle United on Boxing Day after Patrick Dorgu scored the game's only goal midway through the first half. Ruben Amorim's side held on in the second half to secure a 1-0 win at Old Trafford.

They returned to winning ways, even in the absence of captain Bruno Fernandes. The midfielder sustained a hamstring injury during their loss to Aston Villa, and he has barely missed any matches since signing for the club almost six years ago.

United had not won a game since the first weekend of December, when they defeated Wolverhampton Wanderers 4-1 at Molineux. Next up for them is the reverse fixture as they host Wolves on 30 December, and below is a round-up of their latest injury news:
Mason Mount was forced off at half-time in the victory over Newcastle. Amorim said the midfielder 'felt something' before being replaced.

"He wanted to go [on] and that is also a good thing," added Amorim when asked for an update on Mount's condition. "He wanted to go to the second half but we cannot lose more players, if you are not 100 per cent."
Potential return date: December 30 vs Wolves (H) or January 4 vs Leeds United (A)

Fernandes is due to be out of action for a few weeks because of a hamstring injury. The midfielder was absent from the victory over Newcastle on Boxing Day, marking only the third time the Portugal international has missed a game due to injury since joining them.
Potential return date: January

Harry Maguire is still on the mend from an injury and could make a return to United's matchday squad for their Tuesday night encounter with Wolves next week. The defender has been out of action for several weeks due to injury and is nearing a return, although it's uncertain whether they will be fit to return this month.
Potential return date: 30 December vs Wolves (H)

Kobbie Mainoo has a calf injury that has caused him to miss United's last two matches. His return is imminent, but it remains uncertain whether the England international will be fit to play against Wolves or if he'll have to wait until the New Year.
Potential return date: 30 December vs Wolves (H) or 4 January vs Leeds United (A)

Matthijs de Ligt has been out of action for several weeks due to a back injury, but he's edging closer to a comeback. United are hopeful that De Ligt will be fit enough to join the squad for their clash against Wolves on Tuesday, with an update expected from head coach Amorim in the lead-up to next week's fixture.
Potential return date: 30 December vs Wolves (H)
Amad is unavailable for Man United, as he is representing the Ivory Coast at the Africa Cup of Nations. He scored the only goal in the reigning champions' opening game, a 1-0 win over Mozambique.
Potential return date: January.
Bryan Mbeumo is also currently unavailable for Man United, as he represents Cameroon at AFCON. His country face Amad's on Sunday in a match that looks set to decide who tops Group F.
Potential return date: January
Noussair Mazraoui is also unavailable for United as he represents Morocco at AFCON. The hosts currently top Group A after beating Comoros and then drawing with Mali on Sunday.
Potential return date: January

headline: 'Man Utd and Arsenal didn't want me – now I'm one of the top scorers in Premier League'
body: Arsenal host Brighton on Saturday afternoon in what is another must-win game for the Premier League title contenders. The Seagulls have already made the trip to the Emirates Stadium once already this season, where they were beaten 2-0 in the Carabao Cup back in October.

Brighton’s in-form striker Danny Welbeck was involved on that occasion, coming off the bench to applause and adoring chants from fans of his former club. The 35-year-old will be hoping for a more successful outing for his side in N5 this time around, which is easier said than done when facing Mikel Arteta’s Gunners.

Of course, Welbeck shared a dressing room with Arteta for several years. But the Englishman is currently enjoying the finest form of his career, having netted seven goals in 16 Premier League appearances this season, albeit currently struggling with a back injury.

He has managed 0.64 goals per 90 minutes with a goal conversion rate of 28%, making him the joint fifth top scorer in the top flight this season. Welbeck was similarly impressive last season with 10 goals in 30 league appearances, with his latest hot streak sparking suggestions of an outside chance of making Thomas Tuchel’s England squad for this summer’s World Cup.

The majority of Welbeck’s England caps came early on in his career when he still played for Manchester United. The then-promising forward realised a childhood ambition when Sir Alex Ferguson promoted him to the first-team squad in the late noughties.

His breakthrough came in the 2011/12 season when he scored 12 goals, which remains his best season tally to date. Welbeck picked up several major trophies during his spell at Old Trafford, including the 2012/13 Premier League title, though his United future was thrown into doubt after Ferguson’s retirement.

During David Moyes' short tenure, Welbeck was frequently deployed out wide and his opportunities became even more limited when Louis van Gaal took charge. That led to a shock £16million deadline day move to rivals Arsenal in 2014, with Arsene Wenger famously snatching him from Tottenham’s grasp while in Rome for a Pope-related charity event.

Later explaining his bold decision to leave his boyhood club, Welbeck said: "At the time I was playing on the left-wing a lot and in a 4-4-2, which is very difficult for me because I can't make an impact on the game. I can play it to the best of my ability but that's not best for the team, and I could make a bigger impact playing in my preferred position."

He continued: "You start to have thoughts but at that time you're still going to training and I was still giving 100 per cent and giving my all in every single game - that's just me, I'm not going to change that. But you do start to think about what's best for you."

Then-United boss Van Gaal made sure to take a swipe at Welbeck at the time, saying: "He has played, after [his loan spell at] Sunderland, three seasons at Manchester United but he doesn't have the record of [Robin] Van Persie or [Wayne] Rooney and that is the standard."

Welbeck, determined to silence his critics, became a fan-favourite at Arsenal thanks to some crucial goals, including three against his former side, and two FA Cup triumphs. But his five years in north London were marred by repeated injuries.
He left the Gunners in 2019 off the back of a broken ankle suffered in the Europa League group stage, having scored 32 goals in 126 appearances for the club.

A difficult campaign with Watford followed in 2019/20 as the side were relegated. Welbeck then made one of the best decisions of his career by joining Brighton as a free agent in October 2020, while Graham Potter was still in charge.

Welbeck has since racked up more appearances and goals for the Seagulls than either of the two Premier League giants he represented in the past, managing 44 finishes in 179 matches. While not a particularly impressive goal-scoring ratio, the last two seasons have seen the former England international develop into a more mature finisher in front of goal.

This season, he is well on track to reach double figures in all competitions for the fifth time in his career. Speaking about his goal-scoring run, Welbeck told The Argus earlier in the season: "I'm happier than ever. I think the main thing for me is the consistency of staying on the pitch and getting a rhythm of playing game after game after game.

"Unfortunately, throughout my career, I've had some really big injuries that have maybe derailed that, and it's difficult. You have to try and get back into form, you have to try and get back to match fitness and that sort of stuff. But the last couple years have been really good, and I'm feeling really good. Long may it continue.”

headline: Man Utd news: Kobbie Mainoo transfer update as academy graduate could make shock move
body: With the January transfer window just around the corner, Old Trafford is once again buzzing with excitement and anticipation. Manchester United are no strangers to busy windows, although their record in the winter market has been decidedly mixed.

For every Bruno Fernandes and Nemanja Vidic there's been an Alexis Sanchez and a Dong Fangzhuo. January has often proved a tricky period form-wise for the Red Devils too, but shrewd business next month could provide the spark Ruben Amorim's side need to kick on and mount a serious push for a Champions League place.

Links to big-name arrivals have been circulating for weeks, alongside rumours of high-profile departures. While no deals have been completed yet, one thing is certain: when it comes to Manchester United and the transfer window, drama is never far away. With that in mind, here are the latest United-related headlines:

Amorim has admitted that it would be "hard" to sanction a loan exit for Kobbie Mainoo, particularly if United don't source a replacement for him. Mainoo has spent the bulk of the season watching on from the subs' bench, leaving his United future - and his spot in England's World Cup squad - in serious jeopardy.

The 20-year-old requested to leave on loan in the summer transfer window and is expected to push for an exit again in January. But with Amorim's squad looking a little light in midfield at the moment, particularly after Fernandes limped off against Aston Villa last weekend, his request may once again be denied.
"If we are not getting someone [in], then we are shorter [in midfield]," the Portuguese manager said. "Even with a full squad, we are shorter when something can happen here.

"We are a club with a big responsibility, we are dealing with all these issues and in your head, my head, and everyone's heads, we need to win every game, it doesn't matter, there are no excuses, so it's going to be hard for someone to leave the club if we don't get a substitution [new signing]."

When asked whether Mainoo could kick on when he returns to fitness in the absence of Fernandes, Amorim said: "He will have the opportunity that he has all the time. He played in different positions and we talk about the position of Casemiro - he can do that. He can play, if you play with three, like we did in the last game, the position of Mason Mount in this game, he can play there.
"He is going to be the future of Manchester United. That is my feeling, so he just needs to wait for his chance and everything can change in football, even in two days."

Manchester United are reportedly considering a surprise move for former academy graduate James Garner. The 24-year-old spent nine years at Old Trafford and made seven senior appearances before joining Everton in 2022, following loan spells at Nottingham Forest and Watford.

Garner has since established himself as a regular at Goodison Park and, according to the Daily Mail, United are monitoring the possibility of a cut-price reunion. His Everton contract expires at the end of the season, giving the Red Devils a chance to bolster their midfield at minimal cost, with the Merseyside club likely keen to avoid losing him for nothing in the summer.

A return for Garner could open the door for Mainoo to leave on loan and may prove particularly important if Manuel Ugarte - also linked with an exit - leaves the club in January. While United continue to track higher-profile midfield targets such as Carlos Baleba, Elliott Anderson and Adam Wharton, Garner represents a more economical alternative.

Crucially, he would require little time to settle, given his familiarity with the club, and offers reliable energy, work rate and depth in midfield. Garner made just two Premier League appearances for United but featured more frequently in the Europa League, with all seven of his senior outings coming during the 2018/19 and 2019/20 seasons.

headline: 'I played for Man Utd and get grief from their supporters - Liverpool fans are different'
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Paul Ince once shamed the club's supporters for their reaction to him joining Liverpool. And he put the Anfield faithful on a pedestal in comparison, crediting the Kop for their response after he departed Merseyside.
Ince, 58, eventually found his way to Wolves, who make their own trip to Anfield on Saturday. And there's no comparing his relationship with Liverpool's loyalists compared to those at Old Trafford.

The former England international, who has taken aim at United fans before, is understood to have fallen out with Sir Alex Ferguson prior to joining Inter Milan in 1995. However, any vitriol from United fans is largely due to the fact 'The Guv'nor' later joined bitter nemeses Liverpool.

Ince captained Middlesbrough against United and later took the armband with Wolves when he again returned to Old Trafford over the years. And while he's always had a fond relationship with Liverpool's support, the same can't be said for those in Manchester.

"I get a lot of grief from Manchester United fans and I can't understand it," said Ince back in 2002. "They should remember I was part of the team that took the title back to Old Trafford for the first time in 26 years.

"I sweated blood and shed tears in my six years at United and I think I should be respected for that. But all I get is stick whenever I go there because Ferguson once called me a 'big-time Charlie' in some television programme. So now it's a case of, 'Let's wind him up again.'"

Ince, who won two Premier League titles and two FA Cups at United, went on to acknowledge he "didn't leave Liverpool in the best circumstances" after clashing with then-manager Gerard Houllier. However, it wasn't enough to make the fans turn on him.

In fact, he put the Reds supporters in a bracket of their own when discussing the contrast between the two fanbases years later. And those in attendance for the Christmas showdown against Wolves will be hoping to prove much of his praise remains accurate to this day.

"Liverpool European nights, you can’t beat them," he said on the Blood Red podcast in 2019. “They’re special and it is iconic with all the flags. It is amazing. I think the atmosphere depends on the time, doesn’t it? When we look at Old Trafford, because it is so vast now, it is so corporate, it’s not the atmosphere that you do get at Liverpool.

"I love the Liverpool people. They come and support the team, they know football and they back their players. But one thing about the two teams, you never see them boo their players off, or very rarely. They are understanding fans. They are different atmospheres in different ways, but I like the way Liverpool look after their players, look after their own."

Following a dire run of form in recent months, Liverpool now find themselves seeking a fourth straight win at home to Wolves. Victory on Saturday would at least temporarily take Arne Slot's men into fourth, with Chelsea set to host Aston Villa later this evening.

headline: Ruben Amorim gives instant injury update as Man Utd midfield woes deepen against Newcastle
body: Ruben Amorim says Mason Mount wanted to play on after picking up an injury against Newcastle. However, the Manchester United head coach said the club couldn't afford to risk losing another midfielder for an extended period.

United were down to the bare bones against Eddie Howe's side, with captain Bruno Fernandes, midfielder Kobbie Mainoo and centre-backs Matthijs de Ligt and Harry Maguire among those missing. They also saw Mount forced off at half-time, with teenager Jack Fletcher taking his place for the second 45 minutes.

"It's a very important moment for any kid. He's going to hear from his father. He's going to talk a lot about a lot of things, but he needs to calm down and just praise the kid because he's really humble, works really hard, and he deserves this."

Despite the absences, Amorim's team ground out a hard-fought victory thanks to a rare clean sheet. Patrick Dorgu was the unlikely hero, volleying home his first goal for the club in style, and the Danish international impressed in a more advanced role than the one he is used to.
"It was a good hit. I didn't know I could do that, but I was very happy to score my first goal in this stadium as well. It was amazing," Dorgu said after the victory.

"I just took what [Amorim] told me to work on my confidence and stuff. I think I did well today. I just looked at the ball, saw it drop, and I just hit it. I've been practicing in training, so I think that's what helped me."

Amorim also said last December's 2-0 defeat at home to Newcastle played on his mind when making the unexpected decision to switch to a back four. "In the first half, I think we showed that I felt that was the only way to create more danger, to have more opportunities was with the back four with a lot of guys inside," he said.
"Even to keep the ball, because I remember the game last year we lost one against one outside. We just tried to imagine the game and to help the players to feel comfortable."

headline: Man Utd's unlikely hero downs Newcastle as Ruben Amorim gamble rewarded - 5 talking points
body: Manchester United put some early pressure on the teams above them with a hard-fought win at home to Newcastle on Boxing Day. Patrick Dorgu scored the winner, enjoying the freedom given to him by head coach Ruben Amorim.

United had an early sight of goal when Casemiro rose highest to meet a corner from the left but he couldn't keep his header down. They kept plugging away, though, and were rewarded when Dorgu volleyed home a stunning opener midway through the first half.

They were close to a second just before the hour mark when Benjamin Sesko's effort beat Aaron Ramsdale but clipped the top of the bar. Newcastle hit the woodwork themselves moments later, though, with Lewis Hall's 25-yard effort crashing back off the bar with Senne Lammens flailing.

The visitors continued to put the pressure on as the game ticked on, with Anthony Gordon dragging an effort wide. The cavalry arrived moments later, with Eddie Howe introducing Yoane Wissa, Harvey Barnes and Joelinton as his side chased a leveller.

Diogo Dalot missed a golden chance for a second, breaking beyond the Newcastle back-line but lifting his effort over the bar, while Matheus Cunha dragged an effort of his own well wide after a driving run. One goal was enough, though, and here are our talking points from Old Trafford.

Nearly 11 months after joining Manchester United, Patrick Dorgu finally has his first goal for the club. It was a thumper, too, with the Dane running onto Nick Woltemade's headed clearance and thumping the ball out of the reach of Aaron Ramsdale.

Former Lecce star Dorgu clearly had an eye for goal after getting his opener, putting Ramsdale to the test with a low right-footed effort before half-time. He spent the whole game high up the pitch, be that on the right or the left, and caused problems throughout.
Earlier in the season, Ruben Amorim said he wanted to see Dorgu show more of his Denmark form in a United shirt. Odds are this was the kind of thing he was after.

Manchester United saw Bruno Fernandes forced off against Aston Villa, and that will have been a worry. In their last seven league games without their captain in the starting XI, they had taken just one point.

Amorim recognised it would be a tall order making up for the skipper's absence but insisted United had options. Indeed, for the first 45 minutes you'd have been hard-pressed to tell which was the team missing a key player.
United looked down to the bare bones late on, and there was even a rare outing from the bench for Tyrell Malacia. They weren't doing things the easy way, but they won't complain about the result.

After dismissing the idea time and time again, Ruben Amorim appeared to abandon his usual back three - at least at the start of the game. Patrick Dorgu moved into a right wing role in front of Diogo Dalot, with Luke Shaw staying wide at left-back as Ayden Heaven partnered Lisandro Martinez in the middle.

Now, don't get us wrong, there's every chance the change was made out of pure necessity. Both Noussair Mazraoui and Amad are away at the Africa Cup of Nations, robbing United of two more natural wing-back options, while Dorgu might also have been used there were he not filling in for another AFCON absentee in Bryan Mbeumo.
Certainly, the move appeared to catch Newcastle by surprise. A message arrived with Lewis Hall during a stoppage, allowing the visitors to put their own adjustments into force.

United remained on top before adding an extra centre-back in the form of Leny Yoro. That too was a bait-and-switch, though, with the Frenchman moving to right-back and Dalot thrust forward onto the wing.

Before kick-off, some United fans were making the case for Jack Fletcher to start. The teenager had made his Premier League debut on Sunday and might have fancied his chances with Fernandes injured, but instead started on the bench.

At the start of the second half, though, Mason Mount's withdrawal gave the youngster his chance. That meant an advanced role to begin with, and Fletcher was forced to be flexible as others were withdrawn.

Fletcher's twin brother Tyler was also on the bench for United, among a youthful selection, with Tyler Fredricson introduced late on. United might be far from full strength, but the future is starting to look bright.

This time last year, United put in one of their most miserable first half displays of the early part of Ruben Amorim's tenure. They found themselves 2-0 down inside 20 minutes before Amorim ruthlessly substituted Joshua Zirkzee before half-time.
It was a different story this time. Tonight, Amorim's side were the ones starting quickly and their opponents - barring a few brief flashes - didn't really get a foothold until the second period.

There was even time for Zirkzee to pursue a redemption arc on his personal level after arriving for the final half-hour. It was Newcastle doing most of the attacking by then, though, with the hosts' task one of containment, but revenge will have no doubt been sweet.

headline: Jamie Carragher forced into Casemiro admission as Man Utd star makes Liverpool icon eat his words
body: Jamie Carragher has been forced to address previous criticism of Manchester United star Casemiro. The ex-Liverpool defender had taken a swipe at the Red Devils midfielder, stating that "football has left" the Brazilian.

Casemiro's impressive form comes amid speculation about his future at the Theatre of Dreams. He is into the final six months of his contract and his future remains unclear as rumours swirl about potential midfield reinforcements, including Carlos Baleba and Elliot Anderson.
Carragher was forced to give credit to the turnaround. He said: "Not quite yet (laughs). Fair play to him but Man United finished 15th last season.
"You know what, when I look at him? Fair play, he looks a different player physically. I remember that night at Crystal Palace, he looks almost a stone lighter.

"To still be playing for Man United, he was never going to move on with the contract he's got, I think that's the thing with the deals since they last won the league title, that deal was a ridiculous one.
"It's not going to be renewed, that's the first area they look at bringing reinforcements in in January or the summer."
Casemiro has become a key figure in Amorim's squad, a far cry from when Carragher suggested the Champions League victor should "call it a day".

The midfielder came under fire after a lacklustre performance that saw Crystal Palace net four goals against Erik ten Hag's team. Michael Olise bagged a brace while Jean-Phillipe Mateta and Tyrick Mitchell added to United's woes.
The victory marked Palace's first league double over United in 20 years, further deepening the gloom for ten Hag's side as it confirmed their failure to qualify for European competition.

In 2024, Carragher stated: "I think Casemiro should know tonight that he should only have another three games left at the top level. The next two league games and the cup final, then he should be thinking, I need to go to the MLS or Saudi.
"This has to stop because we are watching one of the greats of the modern time. I always remember the saying 'leave the football before the football leaves you'.
"The football has left him. At this top level, he needs to call it a day at this level and move.
"The level of that player, he should not be putting himself through this.
"He is too good of a player to be putting in a performance like that being laughed at by Crystal Palace. He needs to call it a day."

body: Ruben Amorim is under pressure to deliver more after the Red Devils finished 15th last term. The Portuguese coach does not have European competition to distract from domestic performances as they attempt to make their return to midweek football next season.

It is the first time United have been without Champions League or Europa League football in more than a decade, meaning there is an obvious target to aim for. Former Liverpool defender Carragher reckons they should be contention and are worth their current position.

"The bar has been set so low after last season. They spent a good chunk of change in the summer. They should be where they are in the table, qualifying for Europe. The Champions League would be a step too far. They were really good at Aston Villa."

"He [Ruben Amorim] got a pre-season and signings, they have no Europe but they are still not showing it. We are still waiting. The question marks are still there for me, we talk about top four but they are not ready for that."
The ex-United captain believes United still have some way to go. "Man Utd just need to be better," he said.

"We are not going to compare them to the great defensive teams like Arsenal but they need to be better. I still feel that any time I watched Man Utd, as good as they are going forward, teams seem to creat chances so easily.

"If you want to make progress as a football club you have to be harder to beat. They need to improve or we will keep talking about the same problems. If they keep giving up chances and goals like they are, they will never make the next step."

headline: Why Man Utd twins Jack and Tyler Fletcher play for different national teams amid Ruben Amorim call
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim named not one but two Fletcher brothers on his bench for the Premier League clash with Newcastle United on Boxing Day. Jack made his Premier League debut less than a week earlier, coming on as United lost to Aston Villa.

Amorim is short on numbers, with Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo both injured. He expects Mainoo to be back sooner than captain Fernandes, and will have been grateful to be able to welcome back Casemiro after a one-game ban.

The Fletcher twins, sons of former United midfielder Darren, joined the Red Devils from Manchester City's academy in 2023. A reported fee of £1.25million was enough to bring the pair to Old Trafford, where they have been playing at age group level.
Darren was a Scotland international during his playing career, winning 81 senior international caps. Tyler is also in the Scotland youth set-up, but Jack has instead opted for England.

"I think Jack Fletcher did a very good job and that's why when we have this opportunity, we need to give space to guys like Jack and the other ones. So, we'll find solutions to play,” Amorim told reporters on Wednesday.

The brothers were born in England while their dad was part of United's first team under Sir Alex Ferguson, meaning they could choose to represent either England or Scotland. Ferguson's team actually had a game on the day of their birth, but Darren wasn't involved as he'd been sidelined with an ankle ligament injury at the time.

Jack has opted to represent the country of his birth at international level, though he also played for Scotland's Under-16s when he was younger. He played twice for Will Antwi's England Under-19 side during the November international break, scoring in a 4-0 victory over Scotland.
Tyler was on the opposite team that day, captaining the Scottish selection. He also scored his first goal at Under-19 international level in a 2-2 draw away to Latvia earlier that month.
United fans were excited to see both brothers on Amorim's bench for the Newcastle game. "So happy to see the Fletcher twins on the bench together. What a moment for them and their family," one wrote.

"It must be a proud moment for the Fletcher family," a second said. Others, meanwhile, made it clear they would have liked to see Jack Fletcher start the game ahead of Manuel Ugarte, who struggled against Villa on Sunday.

Another became painfully aware of the passage of time when looking at the teamsheet. "From watching Darren Fletcher during his prime back in college to this, football ageing just felt real again," they said.

headline: RAILSTON: United defender Patrick Dorgu responds to Ruben Amorim criticism - 'Never nice'
body: Manchester United defender Patrick Dorgu believes he has responded to Ruben Amorim's criticism with his recent performances. At the end of November, Amorim said he could feel "anxiety" from Dorgu when he picked up the ball, and suggested the Denmark international needed to perform better.
"He needs to be calmer playing the game," said Amorim to a question about what Dorgu needs to improve. "You can feel the anxiety every time Patrick touches the ball. I can feel the anxiety."
Following that press conference, Dorgu lost his starting place. He was named on the bench for the next five matches, but he was recalled to the starting team against Aston Villa last weekend.

The 21-year-old assisted Matheus Cunha for United's goal in the Midlands and delivered another improved performance against Newcastle, scoring in the first half with a brilliant volley to claim three points for United.

Dorgu spoke to reporters following the full-time whistle and was asked how he dealt with the criticism. "Of course it's never nice to get criticism, but you will always get it as a player," he said. "And you need to react well to it, and I think I've reacted well in the last couple of games."
He added: "The manager spoke about my confidence a few weeks ago, so I just looked inside and tried to understand what he meant. And I just tried to build myself up."

Dorgu sought advice from the leadership group in the dressing room, which includes Bruno Fernandes, Diogo Dalot, Noussair Mazraoui, Lisandro Martinez, Harry Maguire and Tom Heaton. "My teammates help me as well," he added. I spoke to Bruno [Fernandes] and some of the leader group in my team. They just try to help me on a daily basis to grow in confidence in training and stuff. "

Dorgu continued: "We have players at AFCON and injured players, so this is my chance to show I belong in this team, and I feel like I'm doing it in the last couple of games, so I just need to keep going and try to keep the manager happy."

Dorgu played on the right, in a more prominent position, against Newcastle. "I've done that in my old team as well, so it's nothing new to me. I'm just happy to score the goal," he said. "I've been training to shoot more in the games and I think I hit it really well. I'm really happy that it went in. I knew already a few days ago [about playing on the right], so I just tried to remember how to play there.
"It's the same, just you come inside to your stronger foot, so sometimes it's even easier to attack and connect with the teammates, so I find it really easy."

headline: Lisandro Martinez reaction showed Manchester United have their warrior back
body: A few months ago, Ruben Amorim said even the Pope couldn't convince him to change his system at Manchester United, but on the second day of Christmas, he gave in to popular demand. If a back three is United's past, then could this back four be their future?

Amorim had been teasing the idea of a change of shape in recent weeks and had worked on it in training, so the ghosts of Christmas hadn't visited him in his sleep and brought about an epiphany, yet however it came about, Old Trafford delighted in the reversion to a flat back four and the end of wing-backs.

There is enough material from the past 13 months to give Amorim nightmares, but this change in formation delivered a change in fortunes as well. After six weeks of blowing chance after chance to go fifth in the Premier League, they finally took it. It might last for less than 24 hours, but it shows that this side is in the hunt for a Champions League spot, even if they spent almost the entire second half on the back foot.

When the teamsheets dropped at Old Trafford, it didn't look like it was the night when Amorim changed his ways, but Patrick Dorgu was right-wing rather than left-wing back. That change caught Newcastle by surprise.

On the touchline, Eddie Howe and Jason Tindall debated a solution, while the Newcastle analysts sat in the press box tried to work out what was happening. The shrugging of shoulders showed they hadn't been expecting this.

A few weeks ago, Amorim had talked of the anxiety he could feel whenever Dorgu was on the ball, so when he watched his left-wing-back-cum-right-winger settle over a dropping ball 16 yards from goal, he probably didn't expect to see a sweetly struck volley whizz past Aaron Ramsdale and into the corner of the net.

Dorgu visibly grew in confidence after that. He forced Ramsdale into a smart save soon after and contributed defensively with one thunderous tackle on Lewis Hall that earned a chest bump from Casemiro, but the loss of Mason Mount to injury at half-time turned this into a rearguard effort.

Fabian Schar saw a shot deflected just wide from a corner and was furious when Newcastle were denied a penalty when his shot was blocked by the arms of Lisandro Martinez. Lewis Hall hit the bar from distance and Anthony Gordon dragged a shot narrowly wide.

United's attacks were few and far between. Benjamin Sesko clipped the top of the bar with a left-footed shot in his last action before being replaced by Joshua Zirkzee, part of a double change that saw Leny Yoro come on, giving the hosts the chance to drop into a back six when required.
And it was needed regularly as Newcastle piled on the pressure. Diogo Dalot and Dorgu were wingers dropping in at full-back as Yoro and Luke Shaw went narrow.

Senne Lammens saved from Joelinton and plucked a cross-shot from Joe Willock out of the air. Anthony Gordon should have done better than swiping a shot over after good work by Harvey Barnes, Schar looped a header onto the roof of the net and then Lewis Miley fired wide from 12 yards.

It summed up Newcastle’s wastefulness in the final third as wave after wave of attack came to nothing. It wasn’t convincing from Amorim’s side, especially after the break, but after four successive defeats without Bruno Fernandes in the Premier League, victory was all that mattered.

Fernandes was in the directors' box to watch his teammates go into battle without him. Amorim had talked of how difficult it was to replace the captain on Christmas Eve and with Mount missing as well, United's creativity is being tested. That this game finished with Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fredricson on the pitch, as well as the lesser-spotted Tyrell Malacia, said everything about the resources Amorim now has at his disposal.

He will need to continue to find solutions over the next few weeks, but the fist-pumps that greeted this victory showed how valuable it was, and the sight of Lisandro Martinez blowing kisses to the Stretford End was a reminder that at least one key man is back in the groove. The Argentine was vital to this defensive effort and proved to be the perfect stand-in for Fernandes.

headline: MARSHALL: United win vs Newcastle can prove turning point as Ruben Amorim hails new trait
body: Ruben Amorim said Manchester United's backs-to-the-wall win against Newcastle United was one of his best as Old Trafford boss after his injury-hit side held on to a valuable three points against the Magpies. United were down to the bare bones after losing Mason Mount at half-time and they had to hold on during a second-half onslaught to earn a 1-0 win that temporarily moved them into fifth in the Premier League.

Although United have produced more convincing performances under Amorim, the Portuguese head coach hailed it as one of his best wins during his 13 months in charge and insists the spirit they showed could be valuable in spreading belief through the squad.

Asked if the win was one of his most enjoyable, he said: "Yeah, especially if you see the second half, we managed to defend sometimes with a back six, but we suffer together, and that is a good feeling. I felt we are here talking about the game, and if we always have this spirit, we are going to win so many games. We need to feel we can win games without playing so well and win with spirit and togetherness."

It was just a second clean sheet of the season and Amorim felt the luck was on United's side against Newcastle when it has deserted them at other times this season. "The feeling is good but if you compare to other games we suffered so much more today, but in certain moments we put everything on the line," he said. "We’re defending every cross, trying to push out the box, that is a good feeling to have but we had so many games we controlled much better and conceded a goal."

headline: MARSHALL: United player ratings vs Newcastle with Lisandro Martinez and Patrick Dorgu excellent
body: United were pinned back for much of the second half and had to produce a defensive rearguard to hold on to the lead given them before the break.
Senne Lammens: Good save from Guimaraes in the first half and solid after the break as Newcastle piled on the pressure. 7

Patrick Dorgu: Took his goal brilliantly and visibly grew in confidence after that. Diligent defensively and remained a real threat running forward. Best game for United. 8

headline: MARSHALL: Amorim hints at new Manchester United undroppable after Newcastle win
body: Ruben Amorim has told Ayden Heaven his place in the Manchester United starting XI is safe if he continues the rich vein of form he has shown in the last couple of games. The 19-year-old has started five games in a row for United and has raised his performance levels during that run, producing an outstanding display in a rearguard defensive effort in the 1-0 win against Newcastle on Boxing Day.

Heaven, a £1million signing from Arsenal last January, has had to be patient for his chance this season but he has taken it when the opportunity arrived and was selected ahead of Leny Yoro against Newcastle. The teenager was named man of the match on TV as United showed tenacity in the second half and Amorim was delighted with the youngster's display.

"Really pleased with Ayden, he’s improving every game," he said. "He’s young but you don’t feel he has a good game and slows the thinking. "He was not playing but he trained really well to be ready when the opportunity comes. If he continues to play like that it’s going to be hard to take his place."

Heaven started in a back four against the Magpies and that meant Patrick Dorgu reverted to right-wing, netting his first goal for the club with a stunning volley. It was his best performance since joining United last January and Amorim felt the freedom afforded the Denmark international in a more advanced role played into his hands.

"It’s the normal life of a player, sometimes you are in a good moment, sometimes you struggle. It depends on the team or the game," the United head coach said. "Maybe the game today, with a lot of transitions, is good for his pace and ability to drive the ball. He played in a position where he can take more risk, that can help him not feel the responsibility."
Amorim also reserved praise for Lisandro Martinez, who captained the team in the absence of Bruno Fernandes and on his first start since February 2.

"He’s a guy with a lot of character, really good on the ball, he won the World Cup, he’s used to that stress and showed today he is a top player," he said. "He’s a small guy but today he did really well against a team who has tall players."

headline: Three ways Man United can line up without Mason Mount amid injury crisis
body: Manchester United showed their gritty side on Boxing Day as they overcame injuries to defeat Newcastle 1-0 at Old Trafford. The Reds were deservedly ahead at the break thanks to Patrick Dorgu's stunning volley which Aaron Ramsdale could only get a palm to.

However, the second half proved to be a backs-to-the-wall effort as the visitors pushed for the equaliser and United were forced to re-evaluate their system. Mason Mount came off at the interval having 'felt something' and it remains to be seen how long he will be out for.

The lingering concern for Ruben Amorim now will be how he lines up should Mount not be fit enough to start against Wolverhampton Wanderers on Tuesday night. MEN Sport has taken a look at three different systems he could deploy.

For the first time under Amorim, United played with a flat back four and it worked. While that four may have turned into a six as the Reds absorbed pressure, the initial system which worked so well in the first half was a 4-2-3-1.

If Amorim wishes to use this again, he could make a relatively straightforward swap bringing Joshua Zirkzee into the starting XI. Some of Zirkzee's best performances have come as a No.10 for the Reds and the United boss has previously admitted the Dutchman can operate as a centre-forward and an attacking midfielder.

The issue with this is that you would be starting both Zirkzee and Sesko meaning there would be no first-team centre-forward on the bench. However, in this current situation, Amorim cannot afford to be too picky.
Having reverted to one four at the back system, Amorim may be thinking: 'Why not try another against Wolves?' In this instance, a 4-3-3 could work if he trusts Jack Fletcher from the start.

After the win on Boxing Day, Amorim said: "Jack [Fletcher] did a very good job. It's a very important moment for any kid. He's going to hear from his father. He's going to talk a lot about a lot of things, but he needs to calm down and just praise the kid because he's really humble, works really hard, and he deserves this."
Like Kobbie Mainoo when he was called upon against Everton under Erik ten Hag, Amorim may feel Fletcher is ready and against the worst team in the league, why not experiment?

Should Amorim feel a back three is needed, he could pick a strong line-up albeit the bench will be compromised somewhat. Luke Shaw or Lisandro Martinez would be casualties in this system despite both playing well against Newcastle which may prevent this change.
Also, like 4-2-3-1, it would mean having to start Zirkzee as a No.10 alongside Matheus Cunha. This again means there would be no first choice striker on the bench.

Amorim has to decide whether he is picking a team to have a strong bench or a starting line-up which has the best chance of winning without relying on substitutes. Ideally you want both but that is a luxury they don't have.

Speaking on his YouTube channel, Ferdinand said:
“Do you know what, Lammens is a solid addition to this squad. He’s going to be Manchester United’s keeper for the next 10 years, no doubt.
“He is as solid as a rock. No frills, just gets it done. Look, you need him to come out to claim it on the edge of his six-yard box, he comes and just takes one through bodies, beautiful to see.
“You want a solid keeper, you know where he’s going to be.

“I bet he’s a boring fella, I bet there’s no much in terms of that but he’s intelligent, a lovely guy, really nice guy but on a night out I don’t reckon he’d be one of the ones you’d want to spend most of the night with, no disrespect, most goalkeepers aren’t anyway.
“But when you get to the football pitch you’d be going, ‘you know what, I hope he’s behind me’, he looks like one of those.
“We’ve been searching for a consistent goalkeeper, someone you know where they’re going to be when you look around.
“In the last seven minutes of extra time he’s come out and took two balls in his six-yard box comfortably. Takes the pressure off the back four, absolute life saver if you’re a defender.
“It’s a great feeling to know where your goalkeeper is exactly going to be when you turn around and Lammens is one of those.”

headline: Man United receive new referee verdict after Lisandro Martinez incident vs Newcastle
body: The former Premier League official Keith Hackett believes referee Anthony Taylor was right not to award Newcastle United a penalty for handball by Manchester United captain Lisandro Martinez.

A shot from Fabian Schar struck the United skipper inside the six-yard box. Martinez claimed to Taylor afterwards that the ball actually hit him in the stomach, although replays appeared to show his arm making contact with it.

Video assistant referee Stuart Attwell checked the incident and took no further action. Hackett, as the former general manager of Professional Game Match Officials Limited (PGMOL), has now weighed in on the decision.

Hackett told Football Insider: "The referee has to judge if the action by the player is deliberate when deciding that an offence has taken place, not every time the ball comes into contact, is it an offence. There is sufficient doubt in this action not to award a penalty kick."

Gary Neville shared at the time his belief that something Martinez did just before the incident stopped a penalty being given. The pundit said during Sky's commentary: After seeing the ball hit Martinez's arm, Neville said: "There is a massive shout.
"Schar hits it, his arm is up above his head, and it's stretched. Is it because he's pushing [Malick] Thiaw?
"That might just save him. He's actually wrestling with the other Newcastle centre-back; his arms are already there.
"If Thiaw is nowhere near him, that's definitely a penalty. I think the fact that he has just had a wrestle with the other centre-back might just save him.

Neville also offered an insight into what the VAR thought about the incident. "He is saying the context is because there's another situation whereby he is fighting with another player and his arms are already up there and he's just not got back down."

The commentator Peter Drury added: "They are calling it mutual contact between Martinez and Thiaw. And that is essentially the explanation for the fact that there won't be a penalty."
Ruben Amorim sung the praises of Martinez after United's victory. He said: "I think he is a guy with a lot of character. He's really good on the ball, and that came with the quality that he has.

"He played [in the] World Cup, he won [the] World Cup. He's used to that stress, and he showed today that he's a top player, and sometimes people talk about the way he defends the box because he's a small guy, but today he did really well against a team that just has tall players."

However, he stopped short of saying the team would be in a better position if he stayed fitter for longer. Amorim instead replied: "No, I don't want to say that because if we don't have more points, it's because of the team, not because of a specific player."

headline: Manchester United handed transfer timeline as player 'says yes' to move
body: The January transfer window is just around the corner, and Manchester United are said to have a number of names that they hope to pursuit. However, there could also be outgoing stars who have failed to make a mark at Old Trafford.

Following a 1-0 win over Newcastle United on Friday evening thanks to Patrick Dorgu's first-half strike, the Reds currently sit fifth in the Premier League standings A tally of eight wins, five draws and as many losses is what Ruben Amorim's men have to show for their efforts this season, as they look to push for European qualification.

It's a polar opposite state of affairs from the club's 15th-place finish for 2024/25, but further investment may be required next month to ensure a strong end to the current campaign. With the market reopening in a matter of days now, the rumour mill has been churning with regards to both arrivals and departures.

As per Gazzetta, Joshua Zirkzee has had a number of "discussions and contacts" with Roma management as of recent, particularly speaking with sporting director, Ricky Massara, and Giallorossi head coach, Gian Piero Gasperini. The publication claim that the Dutch forward has gone as far as "promising" himself to Roma by saying 'yes' to a move when the window opens, as it looks increasingly likely that he will make a grand return to Serie A in mid-January, when Bryan Mbeumo, Amad and Noussair Mazraoui return from AFCON.

However, there is a crutch with regards to United agreeing a deal without finding a suitable replacement. While Mbeumo, Benjamin Sesko and Matheus Cunha have all seen the nod ahead of the 24-year-old, Zirkzee has been a valuable option with regards to depth, featuring in 10 Premier League matches this season.

A loan deal with an obligation to buy looks the most likely scenario for Zirkzee come January, should Roma be happy to agree to a fee of around £35million to take the forward on permanently come season's end. With United seemingly looking to strengthen their engine room next month, it will be interesting to see which names crop up as a potential replacement for Zirkzee.

The MEN says: On paper, a deal with Roma would be a fantastic move for all parties involved. Zirkzee set United back a reported £36.5m last summer when he joined from Bologna, but has failed to make much of a mark in the English top flight.

At the time of writing, he has scored just eight goals from 61 appearances - a stark contrast to the 14 from 58 he managed with Bologna - and should Roma agree to a £35m obligation to buy, it will see the Reds recoup most of the money they paid for him last summer to spend elsewhere.

United are among a wealth of clubs who are currently said to be keeping tabs on AZ prospect, Kees Smit. The 19-year-old midfielder has impressed in the Eredivisie, having broken through the youth academy last year.

This season, the Dutch U21 has racked up two goals and two assists from 15 appearances, instrumental in his club's success as they sit sixth in the league standings. And as a result, a number of teams across the world have had their heads turned.

It's no secret that the Reds are looking to strengthen their engine room in January, given Bruno Fernandes has dropped into a deeper role alongside an ageing Casemiro who sees his future with the club beyond 2025/26 cast into speculation.

However, they will face stiff competition in securing his signature from the likes of Chelsea, Bayern Munich, Barcelona, Newcastle United and Real Madrid, to name a few. Furthermore, AZ are understood to hold a valuation of around £52m on the talent at present, which could prove risky considering he is fairly unproven.

The MEN says: It's a major risk to fork out such a substantial sum on a rising prospect, especially given United's track record with regards to splurging on wonderkids as of recent. Zirkzee and Rasmus Hojlund are examples, with neither player truly living up to expectations at Old Trafford despite their reputation.

Instead, the Reds may be better suited tailing a slightly older player with Premier League experience such as Elliot Anderson, considering the centre of the park is make or break in terms of team success.

headline: RAILSTON: What Ruben Amorim did offers fresh Manchester United hope as Newcastle staff left confused
body: Manchester United won 1-0 against Newcastle in the Premier League on Boxing Day. United opened the scoring in the 24th minute through a brilliant Patrick Dorgu goal, which was the difference at the break. Newcastle started the second half as the better team and came close to equalising, hitting the crossbar, but United defended bravely to see out a victory, which means they move to fifth in the table. Here are the moments you might have missed....
Amorim sprang a surprise with his system in the 4-4 draw against Bournemouth earlier this month and he tweaked his tactics again on Boxing Day, starting the match with a 4-2-3-1 shape.
The biggest surprise was Dorgu's position, as he started practically on the right wing. The Newcastle analysts in the press box sounded and looked confused as they deliberated among themselves.

Amorim has been wedded to the 3-4-3 formation for most of his tenure, but he is finally tweaking his approach depending on the opponent, which can only be a positive. The United boss has shown a willingness to change, and the reaction from Newcastle's analysts proves why it's worth being adaptable.
Newcastle struggled to get to grips with the shape in the opening exchanges. They eventually adapted and warmed to the contest, but it's encouraging to see Amorim tweaking his tactics game by game.

Amorim altered his system again when he made a double change in the second half. Then Newcastle's analysts were overheard questioning whether Dalot was the right-sided winger. Amorim famously said not even the Pope could persuade him to change his tactics, but that stance has softened.
Dorgu had scored just 12 goals in his career before facing Newcastle, so it's likely his wonderful volley from the edge of the box to fire United into the lead was his finest strike so far.
The Denmark international savoured every second of the celebrations, but he was hungry for more after the restart, demanding the ball from his teammates at every possible opportunity.

Dorgu frantically waved his arms to receive the ball in the 27th minute before looping a shot over the bar. Just moments later, he wildy gestured at Luke Shaw to pass it to him from the opposite wing.
It's funny what confidence can do to a player. Dorgu looked like a new signing and delivered the kind of performance that he must produce consistently to nail down a regular starting role.
Matheus Cunha had an opportunity to extend United's advantage with 10 minutes remaining, but his shot was sent wide of the post at the Stretford End, to the relief of Aaron Ramsdale.
Cunha was slumped on the turf and looked like he had nothing else in the tank. The forward had worked tirelessly throughout the game, and he took his time to get back to his feet.

There were suggestions that Cunha's work rate could be an issue before his arrival from Wolves in the summer transfer window. Some pundits suggested he would not provide adequate defensive cover. Cunha has made that look stupid in just a few months in Manchester - he runs his socks off each game.
Dorgu didn't just contribute in the final third against Newcastle, he worked back and provided defensive cover, which saw him make one of the tackles of the game on Lewis Hall.

It was a brilliant challenge, which provoked a roar from the Stretford End. Dorgu also received appreciation from his teammates. Diogo Dalot slapped his back, and Casemiro pushed him as if to say 'more of that'.

The crowd lapped up Casemiro's interaction. The Brazilian received praise from Amorim during the pre-Newcastle press conference and it will be difficult to find a replacement with a similar mentality next summer, but logic dictates it's the right decision to allow Casemiro to leave after the expiry of his contract.

United included brothers on the bench for the first time in 12 years against Newcastle, with Amorim naming Jack Fletcher and Tyler Fletcher in the squad. Jack was handed his debut against Aston Villa, and he was joined by his twin brother, Tyler, who made his first Premier League matchday squad.

Darren Fletcher, their father, looked proud as punch in the directors' box. It was a special moment to have both brothers in the squad, and the occasion became even sweeter when Jack came onto the pitch.
Mason Mount was brought off at the interval - seemingly due to an injury - and Fletcher was introduced. His father was on his feet and applauding following the final whistle.
